data.title: [Linux] Window size fix
data.body:
Work-around for #628

OpenTK on Linux currently does not allow the window to be resized if the border is fixed. We get the resize event for the intended size, then immediately get a resize event for the original size. This was preventing GraphicsDeviceManager.PreferredBackBufferWidth and PreferredBackBufferHeight from having any effect.
Previously reported to OpenTK here http://www.opentk.com/node/3132

The window size currently flip-flops between the default (640x480) and the intended size a few times on Linux due to OpenTK, but finally settles on the intended size.

Also fixed the GraphicsDevice being created far too early on Linux and Windows.

data.title: Mouse Cursor not hidden in XAML based apps.
data.body:
In xaml, mouse must be actively turn off during initialization.

Setting Game.IsMouseVisible =false; has no effect because the code check
against current _isMouseVisible value, which is by false from the beginning.
Now, In order to hide the mouse cursor one must do:
IsMouseVisible = true;
IsMouseVisible = false;

Another thing: The execution path through
MetroGamePlatform.RunLoop()
MetroGameWindow.RunLoop()
which call SetCursor(false), doesn't seem to be active anymore.

data.title: develop - Take out check for GL Error on FrambufferRenderbuffer commands in SetRenderTargets
data.body:
Source: http://www.songho.ca/opengl/gl_fbo.html

FramebufferRenderbuffer should be checked with checkFramebufferStatus(GLFramebuffer) which is being done in the code afterwards.  If we check for GLError here we could be catching errors from previous commands and not this.

This resolves multiple RenderTarget problems for myself which makes heavy use of RenderTargets.

Checked against iOS and Mac Samples.

data.title: Test Framework Improvements
data.body:
The current way tests are setup is cumbersome for development:
- It is hard to find a test for a class as it is so distant from the location where the code is.
- The tests are not included in the platform solution files... most developers probably have no clue they exist.
- The tests are in separate submodule making it impossible to commit a fix+test together.

I suggest we consider a few things:
1. ~~Consider moving at least the basic unit tests into the MonoGame.Framework folder itself:  Ray.cs and Ray.Test.cs.  This probably would only be beneficial if using wildcards in the test project.~~  DONE
2. ~~Move the Tests folder into the main repository removing the old submodule.  Move the test art ("Tests/Assets" folder) into a new submodule.  Move the binaries in "Tests/Libs" into the existing thirdparty libs.~~ DONE
3. ~~Get the tests into the automated build ASAP.  At the very least on Windows~~ and Mac.  If any tests fail we should fix them or disable them.
4. Start making unit tests a requirement for all changes to easily testable classes like math.
5. ~~Add unit tests for the 2MGFX tool.~~

Allow sampler states using parenthesis instead of less-than/greater-than

I've always used the "Texture = (DiffuseTexture);" syntax myself, I assume others do too?

data.title: Fix to the ray-AABB intersection to resolve cases where hitting an edge ...
data.body:
...would return false negatives.

I hit a problem in my title where a ray hitting an AABB on its edge or a corner would intermittently report false negatives (returned null where it was a hit).

I couldn't understand the current algorithm, and comments were full of typos, so I just adapted a C++ algorithm instead and made it a bit safer.

"Works here" but I haven't made specific test cases for it.

data.title: develop - Cleanup Frame Render buffers for RenderTargets
data.body:
Delete Render buffers for each Render Target binding in SetRenderTargets when the render target is passed as null which signifies resetting the Render Target bindings.

This fixes a problem with multiple render targets with DepthFormats other than None. FrameRenderBuffers are generated but are not cleaned up (GL.DeleteRenderBuffers) after they are no longer used. If this is not done and another RenderTarget is attached that does not have the same size then the FrameBufferStatus is invalid with FramebufferIncompleteDimensions.

Tested on iOS and Mac.

data.title: TextureCollection.SetTextures throws NullReferenceException
data.body:
Some effects like DualTextureEffect and EnvironmentMapEffect use two textures.
Once used, the second texture stays at GraphicsDevice.Textures[1] forever.

In case you later dispose the said texture, a NullReferenceException is thrown at: 
Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Texture.GetShaderResourceView()
Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureCollection.SetTextures(GraphicsDevice device)
Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice.ApplyState(Boolean applyShaders)
Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice.DrawUserIndexedPrimitives(...) or DrawIndexedPrimitives(...)

I think we need to call TextureCollection.Clear() at the very beggining of Effect.Apply() and  SpriteBatch.Begin(). 
Or return null from GetShaderResourceView() if _texture is null.

Any thoughts on this one?
I will try to test this on XNA to see if I can get any clues.

data.title: Bugfix: DirectX effect files used sampler states in wrong order.
data.body:
Fixes this issue: https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/1459

Important changes:
- Sampler info stores textureSlot and samplerSlot separately.
- SamplerStateInfo._dirty is now true per default. If it is false per default, then SamplerStateInfo.State will stay null if the parsed sampler state uses exactly the default settings. 
- Rebuilt stock effects.
- Incremented MGFX version.

I have tested it on WinDX with stock effects and lots of custom effects. It fixed a lot of sampler-related problems - even some I wasn't aware of before...
